subclusters.subcluster_name: Insulin/IGF and TOR Nutrient-Sensing Hyperfunction Theory

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Insulin/IGF and TOR Nutrient-Sensing Hyperfunction Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on IIS and TOR nutrient sensing pathways regulating aging via endocrine and metabolic signaling.
Central role of TOR complexes, especially TOR2 and rapamycin inhibition, in lifespan regulation.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: mTORC1 Overactivation Hyperfunction Theory in Age-Related Pathologies
theory_assignments.reasoning: mTORC1 overactivation drives specific age-related pathology (hearing loss) via oxidative stress and autophagy impairment.
Aging caused by persistent wild-type functions including IIS-driven autophagy-mediated biomass conversion.
mTOR as central regulator of metabolism, autophagy, and stem cell function influencing aging.
mTORC1 and mTORC2 complexes regulate aging via lysosomal nutrient sensing and autophagy.
mTORC1 amino acid sensing via ILF3 modulates aging through nutrient sensing and autophagy.
mTOR pathway decline causes translational deregulation contributing to aging.
mTOR-driven gerogenic pathways link aging and cancer via geroconversion and hyperactivation.
Chronic mTOR inhibition extends lifespan by inducing autophagy and modulating cell type-specific effects.
TORC1 inhibition in neurons modulates systemic aging via tissue-specific signaling.
mTOR inhibition by drugs extends lifespan and modulates senescence and metabolism.
Aging caused by continued action of wild-type genes beyond development causing late-life pathologies.
mTORC1 regulates aging via RNA splicing modulation linking metabolism to longevity.
Aging driven by imbalance of multiple signaling pathways including mTOR, IIS, AMPK, and inflammation.
mTORC1 hyperactivation drives aging by disrupting metabolism and growth regulation.
mTOR regulates skeletal muscle aging via autophagy, oxidative stress, and mitochondrial biogenesis.
Aging caused by decline in organismal signaling responsiveness and adaptability.
Sch9 (Akt homolog) promotes aging via metabolic regulation and stress resistance pathways.
mTORC1 activation drives aging-related diseases; mTORC2 has distinct roles in metabolism and lifespan.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Insulin/IGF and TOR Nutrient-Sensing Hyperfunction Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: IIS and TOR pathways regulate growth and aging linking metabolism to lifespan across species.
Late-life hyperfunction of reproduction-promoting genes causes aging via excessive biosynthesis.
mTOR pathway integrates nutrient and growth signals to regulate aging via anabolic/catabolic balance.
GLK kinase promotes inflammaging and aging via proinflammatory cytokine production.
mTOR signaling dynamics regulate cell fate decisions including aging and tumorigenesis.
mTOR inhibition delays senescence and reduces oxidative stress and inflammation in aging cells.
mTORC1/PGC-1 axis drives mitochondrial biogenesis causing cellular senescence via ROS.
Sch9 promotes age-dependent oxidative DNA damage and mutagenesis driving aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Senescence as mTOR/MAPK-Driven Hyperfunctional State Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Senescence arises from cell cycle arrest plus hyperactivation of growth pathways like mTOR causing hypertrophy.
Age-related decline in neuronal signal transduction impairs responsiveness and contributes to aging.
